plist.p: Good afternoon Hong Kong. Good morning London. Could I apologize for my voice. Actually it's a bit throaty this morning, because I was cheering for Spurs at the weekend. Richard also has a bad throat infection, so the good news is Peter Sands is in good health. His voice is very clear. And then I'm going to be really corny and say that these results speak for themselves. I'm generally delighted to report that Standard Chartered and profit in 2007.

Showing the results of our investment program over the last few years in our key growth markets of Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. Profit before tax rose 27% to US$4.04 billion. Income increased 28% to $11.07 billion. Normalised earnings per share climbed 16% to 197.6c. The Board is therefore recommending an annual dividend of 79.35c per share. Now these outstanding results are a reminder of Standard Chartered's transformation over the last few years, but also of its enormous potential. Peter and his team have done a great job in delivering these numbers against the backdrop of turmoil and dislocation in the global financial markets.

Now, these are extraordinary times to be Chairman. And it has been a very unusual time for the banking and financial services industry, unprecedented losses, huge volatility, recapitalization of major banks, no securities firm, investment company, insurance company or ourselves included has been unscathed. And my reflections as a Chairman are that the industry as a whole has learnt firstly the overwhelming importance of liquidity. Secondly, the need to price properly for risk and thirdly the danger of over complexity.

The financial services industry has on occasion become too leveraged, too complex and no one really understood the embedded risk. I am often asked for my views on what this turbulence will mean for our markets in Asia, Africa and the Middle-East, and the degree to which they have decoupled from western markets. What is clear is that the US economy is now facing a period of weaker growth. Whilst there is some evidence of decoupling across our markets, a US slowdown will impact the rest of the world, dampen global growth, slow the pace of trade and will take the heat out of the commodity markets.

If we look back at the last US slowdown in 2001, the export orientated economies of Asia such as Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia were significantly impacted. Although growth rates in Asia will also slow this time, the region now enjoys a degree of insulation and resilience due to stronger domestic demand, economic resurgence in China, growing trade links within Asia and strong policy response from government and central banks. It is easy to focus on China as the growth engine but we should not underestimate the diversification of the Asian economies, the catch-up potential of India, the huge wealth creation in the Middle East and the infrastructure boom across the regions. The emergence of sovereign wealth funds in Asia and the Middle East is emblematic of the shift in wealth that is underway. So while we forecast the GDP growth rates will soften slightly in these markets in 2008, these economies will remain robust and their growth will be significantly higher than that expected in the US and the Euro zone.

Last month I was in Abu Dhabi and I was struck by the enormous wealth creation and extraordinary vision and confidence in the Middle East. I hosted a breakfast for Donald Tsang, Chief Executive of Hong Kong SAR. On that trip, he was on an official trip to the Emirates, surely that sums up Standard Chartered and the world in which we operate.

The group today is extraordinarily well positioned to seize these new realities, thanks to its growing geographical reach and the scale and breadth of its products and capabilities developed in recent years. We have a loyal and supportive shareholder base and in my view an exceptional management.

In May, we welcomed John Peace to the Board as Deputy Chairman and Senior Independent Director, and Sunil Bharti Mittal as an independent Non-Executive Director. We also welcomed Gareth Bullock who is in the front row here to the Board as Group Executive Director in August. In September, Kai Nargolwala stepped down from the Board after eight years. I would personally and on behalf of the Board like to thank him for his significant contribution to the Group's success and I wish Kai every success in the future, but not too much.

We are also very grateful that we will get back to Kai. We're also very grateful to Sir CK Chow, who will retire from the Board this year after 10 years as a Director, Non-Executive Director, and my personal thank you to CK, fantastic Non-Exec.

In my last report to you I was cautious about the outlook but I did not anticipate such extremes as we have seen since then. In the past six months we witnessed big upheavals in our sector. At Standard Chartered we know that complacency kills. We are operating in a period of sustained uncertainty. We have learnt lessons in recent months. We have made difficult decisions and we are constantly reminded of the importance of our liquidity and our capital strength. So my message to you overall is that banking remains a risk-based industry and we therefore will remain prudent in our management and pricing of risk. But we are well placed to take advantage of the opportunities that will undoubtedly arise.

Standard Chartered has shown how it's positioned in the world's growth markets and the strengths of its balance sheet can deliver record results during turbulent times. We are not complacent about the future, but we are confident that we will deliver another strong performance in 2008.
Thank you. I'll now pass over to Richard Meddings. Richard?

Thank you Mervyn, good afternoon Hong Kong, good morning London. As indicated in our pre-close trading statement the Group has continued to perform very strongly, building on an excellent first six months. Standard Chartered has continued to accelerate growth and the performance of the Group is strong as we enter 2008. And there are many notable highlights in 2007, record levels of performance with income exceeding $11 billion and profits in excess of $4 billion, both for the first time. Broad-based headline income growth of 28% with like-for-like organic income growth continuing to accelerate now at 23% for the year, a record high.

Hong Kong has delivered over $1 billion of profit and both India and our MESA region have comfortably exceeded $0.5 billion of profit for the first time. We have continued to invest in the franchise whilst at the same time delivering good EPS growth of 15.8%. Our liquidity and capital positions remain strong.

Now, let me take you through the numbers, starting with the Group as a whole. At the Group level, income has grown 28% during the course of 2007, despite the challenging market conditions wholesale banking income growth has accelerated to 37% in the second half of the year from 30% in the first half. Given this strong income momentum, we have continued to invest in the franchise, costs rising 30%.

There are a number of items of a singular nature in these results. There were two one-off items that in aggregate add approximately $215 million to income, comprising a one-off foreign exchange gain on the repatriation of capital in the Singapore branch following changes in regulation and the valuation gain on shares held in Visa, held by the Group.

More than offsetting these two gains are a number of charges to income. The two Whistlejacket vertical slices have resulted in a $116 million charge to income, the effect of an accounting mismatch on economically effective hedges in Korea ended the year at $155 million, and this is $22 million higher than at the pre-close trading statement. A total cost of $166 million on our asset backed securities portfolio of which 131 million was to income. The strength of the Group's performance has been such that even having taken the net negative impact of all these items, totally over $200 million, we have still surpassed $4 billion of profit before tax for the first time, up 27% on 2006. And this performance excludes as we mentioned at the pre-close, income of approximately $120 million from the previously anticipated sale of our asset management company in India.

The picture on an underlying basis by which I mean excluding Hsinchu, Pakistan, the increased stake in Permata and the three small acquisitions we closed in the second half of 2007, is also very strong. With income growth at 23%, broadly flat jaws and profit before tax growing 27%.

As seen in recent years it is the organic franchise that continues to drive performance. Of the total income growth of 28%, approximately $2.45 billion over 1.94 billion or some 80% comes from the organic business. The underlying rate of income growth of 23% is a record high accelerating again on the momentum seen over the previous three years of 13%, 14%, 18% and now 23%. Our disciplined investment program is paying off. What is also pleasing is that we have two strong engines of growth with each business contributing well over $1 billion of incremental income.

Geographies, trading conditions in the Group's main operating markets generally continue to benefit from strong economic conditions, abundant local currency liquidity and benign credit environments. Moreover in many geographies we are now seeing a clear upwards repricing of risk. Hong Kong had a great year with income growing at a seven year high of 28%. Operating profit in Hong Kong was up 34% year-on-year and the businesses have real momentum. Singapore income was up 43% year-on-year with strong contributions from both businesses. On a headline basis Korea's income was up 3% but profit before tax fell by 29% and I will talk in more detail about Korea later.

Other APR, which includes geographies such as Taiwan, Thailand, Indonesia and China, saw income growth of 52% or 27% underlying with China and Indonesia performing particularly well. Profit before tax increased significantly representing a strong bounce back following the credit issues in Taiwan during the first half of 2006.

In India operating profit was up 71% driven by excellent income growth of 60%. Consumer banking income – Consumer Banking sorry, grew income strongly. Wholesale Banking in India delivered an outstanding performance. Peter will give you a more detailed insight into what is now Wholesale Banking's most profitable geography. Middle East and other South Asia or MESA, which includes Pakistan, Bangladesh and the Gulf region, had very strong income growth of 33% on a headline basis or 26% underlying. Bahrain, Qatar and Jordan all saw income growth exceeding 30%. You'll notice that the Americas, UK and Europe region is showing a substantial loss for the year. You should bear in mind that this geographic segment includes charges relating to Whistlejacket and the asset backed securities portfolio which I will come to later. Expenses in this region have grown by 30% reflecting increased levels of head count and compensation costs as well as new investment.

China. China is beginning to power through in other APRs numbers. Income in China increased 73% from $288 million in 2006 to $498 million in 2007 with about three quarters of income being generated by the Wholesale Banking business. As one of the first four international banks to incorporate locally last April we are investing in a business of meaningful scale and breadth.

In 2007 we have more than doubled the number of permanent staff from 2100 to over 4300 and our local network has expanded from 21 to 38 outlets. We invested over $60 million in the Consumer Banking business alone in 2007 and this high level of investment resulted in a loss of the operating profit before tax level for Consumer Banking. Nevertheless, profits in China overall increased by 72% in 2007 and are now some $180 million. And these numbers ignore the effect of offshore income representing deals done on behalf of Chinese clients booked elsewhere in the network which increased 43% year-on-year to over $60 million.

Let me now talk about the performance of the Consumer Banking business. On a headline basis Consumer Banking delivered income growth of 24% and expense growth of 28% with operating profit before tax growth of 27%. Underlying income growth is good at 15% reflecting continuing strong growth in Wealth Management and SME. As we continue to invest strongly across our franchise, costs have grown faster than income and as expected Consumer Banking produced negative jaws of 4%.

Income. Consumer Banking income growth is increasingly well diversified with 9 individual markets now contributing $200 million or more in income with two markets contributing over $1 billion each compared to only 5 markets in 2005 and at that point no individual market contributing over $1 billion in income.

Wealth Management income now contributes over 45% of total consumer banking income. Other APR with an income growth rate of 60%, MESA with 38% and India with 26% have all performed particularly well. Singapore, Malaysia, Africa and the UK business also grew income by over 20%. Hong Kong saw strong double-digit income growth of 17% reflecting strong growth in SME and Wealth Management.

Turning to costs, Consumer Banking expenses were up 28% or on an underlying basis 20%, and if we focus on this underlying 20% then almost half of this increase is attributable to accelerated investment in future growth. We have invested in distribution capabilities key for both SME and Wealth Management with over 70 new branches in Pakistan, China, Korea, Africa, and Hong Kong. Over 30 new SME centres in Hong Kong, Pakistan, India, and the UAE, 20 new consumer finance outlets in Korea, India, Hong Kong and China, and over 600 new and upgraded ATMs. We have pushed on with product innovation and our Private Bank has now been rolled out in a total of 11 locations.
We are both investing hard but also managing our BAU costs well. BAU costs represent only 7% of the total 20% increase in underlying expenses.

Turning to impairment. The Consumer Banking loan impairment charge has increased marginally from $721 million to $736 million. If you take account of the most recent acquisitions which have contributed a year-on-year increase of approximately $160 million and the reduction in Taiwan, where following the 2006 credit crisis impairment has returned to more normalized levels, there was a small net increase in loan impairment of some $50 million. The issues in the UAE have been contained and Thailand is controlled but stubborn. There has been some stress in India related to the consumer finance portfolio and in Pakistan we face a risk of higher delinquencies if the political situation deteriorates and December delinquencies did deteriorate sharply. However, the sum total of these amounts is not material in the Group context and the overall delinquency indicators for the Consumer Banking portfolio continue to improve.

To summarize for Consumer Banking overall, we have maintained double-digit income momentum. Growth is broad-based reflecting the breadth and scale of our franchise. We have a confident investment agenda for future growth and the asset quality is excellent.

Let me now turn to Wholesale Banking. Wholesale Banking has had an outstanding twelve months. Across the spectrum the wholesale banking business whether viewed by product, by customer segment or indeed by geography is firing on all cylinders. Income accelerated in the second half and grew 34% year-on-year and is underpinned by strong growth in client income of 37%. We continue to deepen client relationships, increasing cross-sell and our shift to higher value products is delivering strong returns.
We are becoming a core bank to more of our clients. We have increased by 93% the number of clients which generate over $5 million income per annum and by 59% those that generate over $1 million.

Expenses grew by 31% year-on-year reflecting higher levels of performance related pay and continued investment in extending our product range and capability. Operating profit before impairment grew by an excellent 37%, so broad-based income growth and strong income momentum.

Wholesale Banking had another impressive performance on loan impairment with a net charge to the income statement of $25 million. New provisions remain low and recoveries in the leases continue to be achieved albeit as we predicted at much lower levels than 2006. The quality of the corporate loan book remains strong and our forward-looking indicators remain robust. Early alerts are stable at very low levels and the cover ratio remains high at 75%.

Risk weighted assets grew by 16% against growth in client income of 37%. We continue to be disciplined in managing the relationship between risk weighted assets and income growth with an ongoing focus on origination and distribution of assets. During 2007 we more than tripled the distribution of Wholesale assets with 40% of this distribution being achieved during the final quarter of the year. Our markets are very much open for business and we exit 2007 with very strong momentum, but as you would expect, we remain vigilant of the external environment.

Income, the 37% growth in client income is driven by strong growth across all client segments and has been strongest in our key geographies. From a product perspective Trade and Lending income grew by 23%, Cash Management and Custody grew 31% and Global Markets achieved 41% growth with strong growth in a broad range of products.

Wholesale Banking expenses were up 31% on a year-on-year basis and 29% on an underlying basis. Of this 29% increase in expenses in Wholesale Bank, 5% relates to incremental investment for future growth, 5% to increased spend on regulatory and control infrastructure and 19% as the direct result of business and income growth. We've achieved productivity increases with BAU expenses growing far more slowly than client income and we are continually looking to improve the flexibility of our expense base. Performance related compensation now constitutes over 40% of total Wholesale Banking staff costs, up from 24% in 2004, 31% in 2005 and 35% in 2006.

Turning to loan impairment, Wholesale Banking loan impairment was a net charge of $25 million to the income statement. New growth provisions remained at very low levels, although slightly up on the levels seen in 2006. Recoveries reduced significantly year-on-year reflecting in part a declining stock of distressed assets. We remain vigilant and have benefited from proactive and robust risk management and an outstanding performance in securing recoveries. Although we remain mindful of the external environment, portfolio indicators remain strong and early alerts are at historically low levels.
Overall, Wholesale Banking has performed strongly with record levels of income growth, well controlled investment and focused management of risk.

Let me now turn to our recent acquisitions, firstly Korea. On a headline basis, Korea's performance shows income growth of 3% with operating profit falling by 29% year-on-year. To better understand the actual momentum of both businesses in Korea, I will strip out some of the headline level noise. Taking account of three items, fair value adjustments of $98 million in 2007 against 106 million in 2006, secondly, the accounting asymmetry on economically effective hedges of $155 million and a charge in the low tens of millions following the recently enacted legislation in relation to dormant accounts. Adjusting for those three items income grew by 15%.

Consumer Banking income was flat year-on-year on a published basis, but up 10% on an adjusted basis with strong growth in SME and Wealth Management, partially offset by a fall in mortgage income. Wholesale Banking performance was up 10% on a published basis but up over 30% on an adjusted basis. Wholesale Banking income momentum has good traction as the investments in people and products begin to pay off.
Expenses are up by 18%, which includes a full allocation of central business expenses which accounts for 6% of that increase.

And now to Taiwan and Pakistan. Despite the uncertain political environment, Pakistan's economy has continued to expand and this is reflected in our performance. To give a sense of momentum by adding the Union Bank financials into the 2006 comparative period, income has grown 17%. We have had particular success in cross-selling Standard Chartered products such as Islamic Finance, commodity products, and export finance capabilities into the Union customer base, with our market share of the export business increasing to 10% in 2007, up from 3% prior to acquisition.
Pre-provision profits increased 19% year-on-year. However, profit before tax on the same basis fell 17% reflecting rising impairments, as the political uncertainties impacted on the portfolio.

Following the amalgamation of Hsinchu and SCB Taiwan, we've been able to press ahead with selling Standard Chartered products through the Hsinchu distribution network. Income in the second six months of the year was 10% higher in Hsinchu than in the first six months reflecting the ability to sell Standard Chartered products through the Hsinchu platform. Expenses have increased half-on-half from 119 million to $135 million. Hsinchu came in well ahead of our expectations at the operating profit before tax level. And we remain confident that Hsinchu will be EPS accretive and deliver double-digit return on investment in 2008.

Turning to the Group's balance sheet. The Group remains strongly liquid, both in part and as a whole with a diverse and growing funding base. Current accounts and savings accounts or CASA grew by 21% year-on-year or 29% excluding Korea and growth was particularly strong in Hong Kong, Singapore, India and MESA.

The ratio of customer loans to customer deposits is a healthy 86%. Approximately 24% of assets are held in cash, net interbank placements, and marketable assets. The Group remains a net interbank lender with approximately $9 billion in net interbank placements at year end. We have a strong liquidity position.

The strength of our deposit franchise has underpinned the increase in loans and advances to customers which grew by 12% year-on-year. The loan book remains conservative. 32% of total Group customer loans and advances are mortgages with an average loan-to-value of 51%. And nearly 80% of Wholesale Banking's loans and advances have a duration of one year or less.

Let me now provide some specific comments on our asset backed securities portfolio. The slide shown here represents the entirety of our asset backed security exposures. Total exposure of $5.9 billion is modest in comparison to the Group's balance sheet, representing around 2% of assets. You can also see we do not have material exposure to the asset classes that have driven the dislocation across the sector.

Let me give you some headlines on the total portfolio, looking at the total column. 33% of the total portfolio is in RMBS, weighted average rating AAA at the end of December, geographically diversified with limited US exposure. Average mark-to-market at the end of the January was 98. 19% of the total portfolio is in CMBS, weighted average rating AA at the end of December; no downgrades, very limited US exposure and average mark at the end of January of 95. 36% of the total portfolio is in other ABS, spread across credit cards, future flow transactions, student loans and auto loans. These are AAA rated at the end of December with an average mark of 95 at the end of January. 12% of the total portfolio is in CDOs where we have written off 100% of the ABS CDOs in the ASG portfolio. The other CDOs remain AAA at the end of December with strong credit enhancement and an average mark at the end of January of 93.

Let me reiterate at this juncture and as we previously stated, the Group has no direct exposure to US subprime and extremely limited in direct exposure. Apart from our involvement with Whistlejacket, the Group has no exposure or commitments to SIVs, SIV-lites or conduits.

If you look at the Asset Securitization Group or ASG portfolio, you can see that 8% of assets or some $218 million are held in ABS CDOs. We've written off 100% of a number of CDOs, including all CDOs that have any exposure to the US subprime sector. These write-offs totaled $122 million. In addition to the $122 million charge, the mark-to-market loss in 2007 across the balance of this whole portfolio is $44 million on the trading book and $38 million on the AFS book taken to reserves. Given this significant dislocation in the external market this relatively small charge is testament to the strength of that ASG book.

Turning now to the ex-Whistlejacket assets which all reside in our available for sale portfolio, we purchased approximately $1.7 billion of ex-Whistlejacket assets as part of the deleveraging of the fund between August and November 2007. We have subsequently sold over $500 million of these ex-Whistlejacket assets resulting in the year-end position of just over $1billion. You'll remember that alongside other capital note-holders we transacted two vertical slices during November and December, where we exchanged our holding of Whistlejacket capital notes, very representative portfolio of Whistlejacket assets totaling $3.3 billion. These assets were acquired at market value and the acquisition resulted in a fair value adjustment taken against income for a total of 116 million. The ex-Whistlejacket assets have no direct exposure to subprime. There is some limited indirect exposure included in the $169 million of CDO ABS assets. And this $169 million exposure had already been written down by around 20% on acquisition.

Between the acquisition of these assets and 31st of December there was a further mark-down to reserves of $45 million. To-date there has been no impairment of any ex-Whistlejacket assets and the weighted average credit grade of the entire portfolio is AAA rated. The vertical slicing also resulted in around $1.27 billion of financial institutions paper been taken on to the Group's balance sheet. These are large US, European and Australian commercial and investment banks and non-monoline insurance institutions with a weighted average credit grade of AA minus.

Let me just summarize what I've told you in terms of the impact on the income statement and reserves. This slide splits the impact on P&L and reserves in both 2007 and up to 31st of January 2008. And as you can see, despite the market dissipation, incremental marks taken until the end of January 2008 have been minimal and reaffirm the confidence we have in the quality of this portfolio. You can see the $116 million loss on the vertical slices. You can also see that in 2007 the impact on P&L and reserves of the whole portfolio separate to the $122 million charge was a total of $83 million to reserves and $44 million to P&L. In 2008 the impact until the end of January was $13 million to P&L and $36 million to reserves.

Capital, you can see that we have continued to strengthen our capital ratios in the second half of the year and are comfortably ahead of our target ranges with a total capital ratio of 16.7% and Tier 1 of 9.8%. Standard Chartered transition to Basel II on the 1st of January 2008 and if the 2007 year end position were calculated on a Basel II basis, the Tier 1 and total capital ratios would be 9% and 15.2% respectively.

Outlook. We ended 2007 with strong momentum in both businesses and the Group has had an excellent start to 2008 particularly in Wholesale Banking, which had an excellent January. The bank is in great shape. The foundations are firm. We are extraordinarily well placed to capture the huge opportunities in our markets. There is more breadth and scale in the Group and our strong performance in 2007 is well spread across multiple products and multiple geographies.

The level of risk and uncertainty in the external environment however makes the horizon more difficult to read. So attempting to provide precise guidance on our outlook is more difficult this year. We know what you expect us to deliver, double-digit income growth, double-digit earnings growth and mid to high teens ROE.

Over the last few years we have been building a track record of consistent delivery of superior financial performance. And we are committed to keep building on that track record. We will not stop investing, given the opportunities we are seeing in our markets and we will continue to flex the pace of investment to insure costs grow broadly inline with income growth. We will remain vigilant in our management of risk.

2007 was a year of strong performance, a year of delivery despite the external turmoil. We enter 2008 amid almost unprecedented market volatility and uncertainty but in great shape with great momentum. Thank you and I'll now hand over to Peter.

Thank you, Richard. Good afternoon Hong Kong and good morning London. 2007 was my first full year as Chief Executive of Standard Chartered. It's been quite a year. Given the scale of the storms sweeping through financial markets, I'm delighted with what we've achieved. Despite all the turbulence, despite the financial shocks and uncertainties, we have once again delivered record profits, a great set of numbers. And, we haven't done this by slowing down or by squeezing the business. We have invested in both our businesses at record levels. We've stepped up the pace of organic growth. Underlying income growth at 23% is faster than we have ever achieved. And we continued to make acquisitions, six since our last set of results.

We have not been unscathed by the financial crisis nor do we expect to be immune as it continues to unfold. But our disciplined approach to running the bank, focusing on our strategic priorities has stood us in good stead, and will continue to do so. We start 2008 confident but not complacent, acutely aware of the dangers, ready to grab the opportunities. The bank is in great shape. Both businesses have begun the year well. 2008 will undoubtedly be testing, but it will also be exciting with new opportunities emerging alongside new challenges.

Our performance in 2007 was underpinned by firm foundations in the way we manage our liquidity, capital, risk profile and costs. We are a very liquid bank with a well diversified retail funding base and a conservative balance sheet. As Richard said we continued to see strong growth in customer deposits. We have a healthy A/D ratio, the ratio of customer loans to customer deposits at 86% and 24% of our assets are in cash, net placements and highly liquid securities. Many years of managing in highly volatile markets mean we have always taken a proactive approach to managing our liquidity.

We're also very well capitalized. Our ratios are well above our target ranges reflecting deliberate and effective management of the capital base. In September 2007, we raised 2 billion of Tier 2 capital. Despite stressed market conditions, the issue was more than five times oversubscribed.

We are disciplined on the risks we take. We have no direct subprime exposure and very limited indirect exposure to US subprime assets. Our entire exposure to all asset-backed securities including CDOs amounts to less than 6 billion. We have faced challenges and taken some losses as a result of the financial turmoil. On Whistlejacket and on our asset securitization portfolio, the profit and loss impact was 300 million in total. On the other hand, we've had an outstanding performance on the corporate loan portfolio and kept a tight grip on consumer credit. We've also had to take some very difficult decisions such as on Whistlejacket. We worked very hard for several months to find a viable way forward for Whistlejacket and are disappointed that we were unable to do so.

Overall, I am confident that our risk approach, our strategy for balancing risk and return and the systems and processes that underpin this are working well. We are disciplined and selective in the risks we take. We are alert and anticipatory in our actions and because things always change, no one really predicted what has happened over the last few months. We learn fast from our own mistakes and from those of others.

We also take a very disciplined approach towards the management of our cost base. We continue to drive for greater efficiency in everything we do and to manage our investment program on a dynamic basis. We are not going to stop investing for growth. The opportunities in our markets are hugely exciting and now is the time to grab them. But as always we will pace and scale this investment taking account of changes in our markets and in our own performance. These firm foundations will prove critical to our continued success as we face the challenges ahead. The turmoil in financial markets is far from over. We expect further shocks, further surprises. It would be naïve to pretend to know what is going to happen, foolhardy to assume we are going to be immune.

We also anticipate strains in the global economy with the slowdown in the US having at least some effect on our markets in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. How profound that effect will be, we don't know, but we are certainly anticipating some degree of stress in certain countries and certain sectors.

We also see a range of political risks in our markets. Kenya and Pakistan are two examples. Yet as a bank that has grown up in the emerging markets over more than 150 years, we have plenty of experience of dealing with such issues.

Alongside these external challenges we also face one big internal challenge that of managing extremely rapid growth. This is all about attracting and developing exceptional talent, ensuring our culture and values remain robust, ensuring our control systems and infrastructure keep pace with the growth of our businesses. In these sorts of markets it's absolutely vital that the pursuit of growth doesn't undermine our control and our discipline.

Alongside these challenges new opportunities are emerging. We're hiring excellent talent from our competitors, who are attracted by our strength, brand and growth potential. We're seeing a flight to quality with a good inflow of deposits and we're seeing better pricing and differentiation of risk. The return of more rational pricing of risk is undoubtedly good for us and for the industry. And we're seeing opportunities to deepen our relationships with our customers. It's at times like these that it's critically important to be clear on your strategy and priorities. We are, we have a consistent clear strategy, well understood by staff, customers and investors.

Back in 2003, we said we wanted to be the world's best international bank leading the way in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. That is still our aspiration, and we're making good progress on that journey. And our near term priorities remain consistent. This time last year, I laid out a management agenda for the year ahead. It's the same agenda this year. The only change is that last year the first item was accelerating organic growth. We did exactly that with an increase of underlying income growth from 18% to 23%. This year I'm being perhaps a bit more conservative, simply saying sustained organic momentum. We want to continue to grow the business at pace.

Let me talk a bit about how we did accelerate organic growth in 2007, starting with our biggest business, Consumer Banking in Hong Kong which delivered a 22% increase in profits on the back of a 17% increase in income. This is the first time in six-years that this business has delivered double-digit income growth. What drove this performance, a strong growth in Wealth Management with income up 25% and in our SME business up 36%. We have opened two dedicated SME banking centres and now have nearly 40,000 SME customers. We stepped up investment in Consumer Banking in Hong Kong during 2007 and have seen immediate results. We will continue to invest in this business.

Wholesale Banking in Hong Kong also had an outstanding year with profits up 50% and income up 46%. In fact, Hong Kong as a whole, with profits up 34% to just under 1.2 billion, made more than the entire Group did in 2001. But the individual business that contributed the biggest increase in profits was Wholesale Banking in India where profits were up 299 million or 91% to 626 million on the back of an 82% increase in income.

Now, Wholesale Banking's largest business, this is a superb franchise. We have added more than a thousand clients over the last three years and have more than a hundred relationships generating income of more than $1 million. We're investing in front line staff and new products and in infrastructure, seizing the opportunities emerging from India's rapid economic growth and the dynamism of its corporate sector. With 83 branches across the country, Standard Chartered has the largest network of branches among foreign banks in India. Including our global shared service centre in Chennai, which provides operational and technology support to our businesses across the world, we employee 18,000 people in India, making it by far our largest operation anywhere. Overall, including Consumer Banking, India broke through $1 billion in income for the first time in 2007, growing 60% to 1.3 billion with profits up 71% to 690 million. In fact, India has generated more profits in 2007 than in 2006 and 2005 put together.

But it's not just in our biggest businesses and markets that we've seen accelerated growth. We're also seeing the benefits from investments we've made to build new engines of growth. Richard has already talked about China, where we are investing heavily and seeing very rapid growth in income, up 73% and profits up 72%.

Nigeria is another example. Nigeria is a country with around 6% GDP growth, 140 million people and a rapidly growing middle class. Over the past three years we have invested in building a full range of products in both Consumer and Wholesale Banking. In 2007, we doubled the number of branches to 12 and now employ about 350 people. As a result of this investment, our income in Nigeria increased by over 62% to over 140 million and profits by 87%. In 2008, subject to approval, we plan to double again the size of our branch network in Nigeria.

Another new engine of organic growth is The Standard Chartered Private Bank. Launched just nine months ago the Private Bank is making excellent progress. With 11 offices across 7 markets and a 118 relationship managers, the Private Bank has 10 billion of assets under management, AUM, of which 28% is from 1,300 clients who are entirely new to Standard Chartered. Whilst it's still very early days, we are seeing that our unique combination of local heritage and international capability, our ability to offer a broad range of onshore and offshore wealth management products, and our distinct brand are proving enormously appealing to our customers.

The acquisition of American Express Bank, AEB announced last September will turbo charge the growth of our Private Banking business adding over 22 billion in AUM, new booking centres, additional products and capabilities and another 120 experienced relationship managers.

The second item on the management agenda for 2007 was delivering on acquisitions. This will remain a top priority for 2008. 2007 was undoubtedly a challenging year for our business in Korea. Whilst externally reported performance was adversely affected by a number of one-off items as Richard has described, the fact is we are still not satisfied with our performance even after adjusting for these effects. I have changed the management team in Korea and we are now executing a range of strategic initiatives to reshape the business, to accelerate income growth, to improve productivity and to enhance return on capital. We are confident that SC First Bank is fundamentally a great business, a large growth platform in a very big, growing economy. It will be a powerful engine of sustained profit growth for the Group.

In Pakistan, we have made rapid progress with the integration of Union Bank. Today, we are the sixth largest bank in the country in terms of profits with over 170 branches in 39 cities. However, the political environment has had a negative impact, particularly on loan impairment and we're entering 2008 with a somewhat cautious stance.

In Taiwan, we've made good progress since amalgamating the businesses in June. We are on course to meet our target of delivering double-digit return on investment and earnings per share accretion in 2008.

While our acquisitions in Korea, Pakistan and Taiwan were primarily about achieving critical mass and distribution in key geographies, the rationale for the acquisition of AEB was to reinforce our capabilities and scale in two key businesses across the world, Private Banking and Financial Institutions. I've spoken already about Private Banking. In Financial Institutions, AEB will double the size of our dollar clearing business and give us direct yen and euro clearing capability, as well as a sophisticated sales and service model.

AEB will also extend our reach into a number of new countries. Following completion of the transaction, Standard Chartered will be represented in over 70 countries. We expect to complete this transaction shortly and look forward to welcoming AEB's 2,800 staff into Standard Chartered. Our detailed planning for the integration is going well and has confirmed our initial view of both the scale and cost of the integration task, as well as the magnitude of the cost and revenue synergies. This is a highly complex integration spanning 47 countries and involving the integration of high volume transaction systems but the prize is also very significant. We anticipate that 2008 integration costs are likely to be around 150 million. So, the acquisition is likely to be slightly dilutive this year, net of underlying earnings and early synergies. We remain confident that AEB will be earnings accretive in 2009 and will deliver a double-digit return on investment. This is a great deal, strategically compelling, financially very attractive. We're bringing on board some highly talented international bankers with a strong cultural fit.

In the second half of 2007, we announced four other capability driven acquisitions, all much smaller than AEB. Pembroke, a specialist in aviation finance, which will reinforce our ability to play a part in the rapid growth of aviation across our markets. Harrison Lovegrove, an oil and gas advisory boutique, which adds to our existing strength in the energy business. Third, rather oddly named, A Brain, a fund administration company in Korea which brings new capabilities and customers to our securities services business. And UTI Securities, an equity brokerage and advisory firm in India which will enable us to provide a broader range of Wealth Management products to our retail and private banking clients.

In January, we also announced the acquisition of the Yeahreum, a mutual savings bank in Korea which will enable us to broaden yet further our product offering. We completed this transaction yesterday.

The logic behind all these capability driven acquisitions is to extend and deepen our product range and expertise, enabling us to serve our clients more effectively across a broader range of needs. They add fuel to our organic growth.

So what can you expect from us in the year ahead? We will continue to stick to our strategy. We will continue to focus on deepening our relationships with our clients and we will continue to be proactive and disciplined in managing our liquidity, our capital, our risk profile and our costs.

We will keep investing to sustain our organic growth momentum. In China, for example, we started 2007 with 21 outlets and ended with 38. By the end of this year subject to regulatory approval we anticipate having at least 60 locations. This year we celebrate 150 years of being in China and India. We have deep roots in these markets and they are a huge part of our future.
We will deliver on our acquisitions. We'll get Korea back on track. We'll deliver earnings accretion in Taiwan. We'll complete the AEB transaction and drive the integration.

2007 was a great year for Standard Chartered. We weren't unscathed by the financial crisis, but we delivered record results. 2008 will not be smooth sailing for the banking industry. The sea is rough. The winds are strong. We do anticipate further challenges, new shocks and surprises. We do not expect to be immune. We will be confident but not complacent, bold yet vigilant. We have weathered many difficult periods in our long history as a Bank. I can assure you we have never been in better shape. Thank you.
